comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consuelo_Vanderbilt "Consuelo Balsan (formerly, Consuelo, Duchess of Marlborough; nee Vanderbilt) (2 March 1877 – 6 December 1964), was a member of the prominent American Vanderbilt family. Her marriage to Charles Spencer-Churchill, 9th Duke of Marlborough became an international emblem of the socially advantageous, but loveless, marriages common during the Gilded Age."

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: One of the pictures on the Wikipedia page seems to have the same long string of pearls and possibly the same dress. The photo source in Wikimedia is www.persephonebooks.co.uk/the-shuttle.html which, in turn identifies the picture as being from Country House Camera, a book by Christopher Simon Sykes. This suggests a society photographer working on location, but so far I haven't identified the photographer. According to Cash for titles: The Billion-dollar ladies By Daisy Goodwin UPDATED: 14:00 EST, 14 August 2010 www.dailymail.co.uk/home/you/article-1302195/Cash-titles-... a long string of pearls was a wedding gift and once owned by Catherine the Great.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: See her elder son and comments at

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: A 2010 blog post on French Sampler thefrenchsampler.blogspot.com/2010/11/consuelo-vanderbilt... shows a larger photo from which the Bain photo is a crop and the cover of a book about Consuelo and her mother Alva that uses the same photo. Unfortunately, I don't see the photo sources cited. But Goodwin's Weekly : a thinking paper for thinking people. (Salt Lake City, Utah), 23 Dec. 1911, page 36 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/2010218519/1911-12-23/ed-... uses the larger photo (looking more like a studio photograph), credits Underwood & Underwood, and calls it "the latest photograph of the Duchess of Marlborough." If you want to overdose on Consuelo, take a look at www.pinterest.com/larrytenney/consuelo-vanderbilt-1877-1964/. This resource led me to the Goodwin's Weekly piece.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: She was frequently in the news for her charitable activities and was an active (but non-violent) supporter of votes for women. The sun., February 07, 1915, FOURTH SECTION PICTORIAL MAGAZINE, Page 8, col 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1915-02-07/ed-... identifies her as chair of a group of "American Women of England" who were organizing war relief efforts, such as opening a hospital for wounded soldiers and sailors. She turned her own Blenheim Palace into a hospital. See, for example, The North Platte semi-weekly tribune. (North Platte, Neb.), 12 March 1915, lower right. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/2010270504/1915-03-12/ed-...

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: swanq: Thank you for bringing her full identity to our attention here.  We'll include this info. next time we update.
